details.detail: Greek portable icon / Ethiopian storage box in a ‘triptych’ style with painted wings. Greek portable icon of the ‘Psychosostria’ (Saviour of souls) type depicting Mary and the Child on a golden background; two small figures of saints in the right and left upper corner. Mary is depicted wearing a burgundy robe over a green tunic; Christ is garbed in yellow dress with green ornamental bands. The very small portable icon has been encased in a modified wooden storage box that unfolds ‘triptych’ style wings upon opening. Due to the left wing of the ‘triptych’ having become loose, the original set-up of the box has been disturbed: The depiction what is now the left wing was originally part of the painting adorning closed outside of the box; now, it has become part of the opened triptych itself. The ‘wings’ of the triptych are adorned with crudely executed paintings in black and red outlines on wood: Left wing open: The crucifixion and a weeping Mary are depicted on what is now the left wing of the ‘triptych’ box, however, due to the change of the original set-up the depiction of the crucified Christ has been cut in half so that only the right side of his body is visible. Right wing open: A figure of a saint is depicted under a canopy on the right open wing of the ‘triptych’ box, with ornaments in the background. Right wing closed: The second part of the Crucifixion scene depicted on Left wing open with a male figure (John?) under the right side of the cross.
